column3: Granger Predictability of Oil Prices after the Great Recession
column4: Journal of International Money and Finance
column18:
Real oil prices surged from 2009 through 2014, comparable to the 1970's oil shock
period. Standard explanations based on monopoly markup fall short since inflation
remained low after 2009. This paper contributes strong evidence of Granger (1969)
predictability of nominal factors to oil prices, using one adjustment to monetary ag-
gregates. This adjustment is the subtraction from the monetary aggregates of the
2008-2009 Federal Reserve borrowing of reserves from other Central Banks (Swaps),
made after US reserves turned negative. This adjustment is key in that Granger pre-
dictability from standard monetary aggregates is found only with the Swaps subtracted.
column19: Max Kenneth Gillman (Role:Author); Szilard Benk (Role:Author)
column30: Wrote manuscript; designed the work; follows up a 2009 article of mine with a different coauthor.

column3: "International Business Cycle and Financial Intermediation"
column4: Journal of Money, Credit and Banking,
column18: The paper extends a standard two‐country international real business cycle model to include financial intermediation by banks of loans and government bonds. The paper contributes an explanation for both the United States relative to the Euro‐area, and the United States relative to China, of cross‐country correlations of loan rates, deposit rates, and the loan premia. It shows a type of financial retrenchment for the United States relative to both Europe and China following a negative bank productivity shock, such as during the 2008 crisis. After 2008, results suggest that the Euro‐area has been more financially integrated with the United States, and China less financially integrated.
column19: Tamas Csabafi (Role:Author); Ruthira Naraidoo (Role:Author); Max Kenneth Gillman (Role:Author)
column30: Wrote the manuscript; designed the study.

column3: "Hyperbolic discounting and growth without commitment: On the resolution of time inconsistency under continuous time"
column7: Volume 85, Issue S2, December, pages e45--e74.
column18:
We analyse the time-consistent intertemporal behaviour of an individual
who discounts the future hyperbolically (HD) in the absence of commit-
ment. In continuous-time, we extend Barro's (Quarterly Journal of Eco-
nomics, Vol. 114 (1999), pp. 1125–1152) analysis of a sophisticated
present-bias in a deterministic setup and characterize consumption in an
analytically tractable way. Furthermore, we embed this analysis into a
flexible AK model. Greater present bias increases the consumption-
capital ratio, decreases the steady-state growth rate, while it increases
the interest rate-growth rate wedge. Dynamically, as the interest rate
fluctuates over the business cycle, a greater present bias causes the
consumption-output ratio to be more procyclical and volatile, thus help-
ing to resolve the consumption-output puzzle. In the transitional
dynamics, greater present bias causes a lower steady state capital stock.
All of these effects are only present or at least more pronounced under
HD than present value-equivalent exponential discounting.
column19: Max Kenneth Gillman; Frédéric Tournemaine; Christopher Tsoukis

column3: "Nominal Interest Rates and Inflation Rate Inversion: Bank Shocks and the Great Recession",
column4: Contemporary Economic Policy; revision near completion
column18: The paper explains the inversion of interest rates and the inflation rate in the US during and after the Great Recession, relative to the norm of higher nominal interest rates than the inflation rate. It does this with a simple model except for the inclusion of a micro founded bank sector to produce a substitute to money in exchange, allowing avoidance of the inflation tax. This endogenous velocity enables a sequence of shocks to the bank sector and the goods sector to explain with the model the rate inversion as seen in the 2007 to 2017 data. To do this, it combines a sequence of initially negative bank productivity shocks with a sequence of subsequently negative goods sector productivity shocks. The results are interpreted in terms of the bank crash during Great Recession and a below trend recovery in goods sector productivity after the Great Recession.
column19: Max Kenneth Gillman; Tamas Csabafi; Ceri Davies; Michal Kejak

column3: Time for Positive Interest Rates for Savers
column18:
Time for Positive Interest Rates for Savers
Federal Reserve interest rates of 2% to 2.25% aren’t neutral if the inflation rate is 2.61%.
4 Comments 
Nov. 1, 2018 1:10 p.m. ET 
 
Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell speaks in Washington, June 13. Photo: michael reynolds/EPA/Shutterstock 

In “Pause Interest-Rate Hikes to Help the Labor Force Grow” (op-ed, Oct. 26), Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis President Neel Kashkari is mistaken in two important ways. Federal Reserve interest rates of 2% to 2.25% aren’t neutral if the inflation rate is 2.61%, as it is as of the third quarter of 2018. This gives a negative real interest rate of at least 0.36%. Only a positive rate of real interest in the 2% to 3% range is “neutral,” as during phases of the high-growth era of the 1980s and 1990s.
The Federal Reserve’s forcing of negative real interest rates for most of the 18 years since 2000, with the exception of about three years, has encouraged the substitution of capital for labor. This means the labor force gets paid less. This can help explain why the labor participation rate fell from 2000 to 2017, and now is finally starting to turn upward as interest rates rise.
Note that the Fed targets the personal consumption expenditures deflator index, and not the consumer price index, as a possible defense for President Kashkari. Everyone else across the globe uses the CPI as the key price-index measure of inflation.
column19: Max Kenneth Gillman; David C Rose

column3: "A Human Capital Theory of Structural Transformation",
column4: Center for Economic Research and Graduate Education - Economics Institute (CERGE-EI Working Paper Series
column18: The paper presents a human capital based theory of the sectoral transformation along the balanced growth path equilibrium. Allowing a small upward trend in the productivity of the human capital sector, combined with differential human capital intensity and constant productivity across sectors, output gradually shifts over time from relatively less human capital intensive sectors towards more human capital intensive sectors. Sectors intensive in the factor that is becoming relatively more plentiful find their relative prices falling, their "effective productivities" rising at differential rates inversely to their relative price decline, and their relative outputs expanding. Adding more sectors of greater human capital intensity causes labor time to decrease across existing sectors, and by relatively more in the least human capital sectors. literature.
column19: Max Kenneth Gillman
column24: UMSL Friedrich A. Hayek Professorship Endowment Fund

column3: "Interest Rates with Optimal Inflation Tax Avoidance"
column4: Journal of Money, Credit and Banking.
column18: This paper explains real US short term government bond rates through a general equilibrium monetary economy with optimal inflation tax avoidance. The effective inflation tax adds to the shadow cost of consumption, forms an intertemporal wedge, and explains variation in real bond rates for the US fiat era, post 1970. There is a high correlation between rates computed using the model's asset pricing equation and those found in the data. Breaking the sample period into pre- and post-2008 subperiods demonstrates how increasing bank productivity pre-2008 helps to better match the level of real rates.
column19: Tamas Z Csabafi (Role:Author); Max Kenneth Gillman (Role:Author); Ceri R Davies (Role:Author); Michal Kejak (Role:Author)

column3: "The Welfare Cost of Inflation with Banking Time"
column4: BE Press Journal of Macroeconomics: Advances
column18: The paper presents the welfare cost of inflation in a banking time economy that models exchange credit through a bank production approach. The estimate of welfare cost uses fundamental parameters of utility and production technologies. It is compared to a cash-only economy, and a [Lucas, Robert Jr. E. 2000. “Inflation and Welfare.” Econometrica 68 (2): 247–274.] shopping economy without leisure, as special cases. The paper estimates the welfare cost of a 10% inflation rate instead of zero, for comparison to other estimates, as well as the cost of a 2% inflation rate instead of a zero inflation rate. A zero rate is statutorily specified as the US inflation rate target in the 1978 Employment Act amendments. The paper provides a conservative welfare cost estimate of 2% inflation instead of zero at $33 billion a year. Estimates of the percent of government expenditure that can be financed through a 2% vs. zero inflation rate are also provided.
column19: Max Kenneth Gillman
column29: F.A.Hayek Professor of Economics History Endowment Fund
column30: Sole author

column3: International Business Cycle and Financial Intermediation
column4: Working Papers 1015, University of Missouri-St. Louis, Department of Economics.
column18: The paper extends a standard two-country international real business cycle model to include financial intermediation by banks of loans and government bonds. Taking in household deposits from home and abroad, the loans are produced by the bank in a Cobb-Douglas production approach such that a bank productivity shock can explain financial data moments. The paper contributes an explanation, for both the US relative to the Euro-area, and the US relative to China, of cross-country correlations of loan rates, deposit rates, and the loan premia. It provides a sense in which financial retrenchment resulted in the US following the 2008 bank crisis, and how the Euro-area and China reacted. The paper contributes evidence of how the Euro-area has been more financially integrated with the US, and China less financially integrated, with the Euro-area becoming more financially integrated after the 2008 crisis, and China becoming less so integrated.
column19: Max Kenneth Gillman

column3: "International Business Cycle and Financial Intermediation,"
column4: CEU Working Papers 2018_7, Department of Economics, Central European University.
column19: Ruthira Naraidoo; Tamas Csabafi; Max Kenneth Gillman

column3: "Nominal Effects on Oil and Gold Prices in Low and High Volatility Markov Switching Regimes"
column4: International Review of Economics and Finance
column18: Using Markov-switching regimes within a vector autoregression framework, the paper contributes that in high volatility regimes US real oil, gold prices and the US dollar exchange rate index can all be Granger (1969) predicted by the US M1 aggregate minus Central bank liquidity swaps (Swaps) and by the CPI inflation rate less energy prices (CPIE). These results support an apparent lack of money neutrality in real asset prices that policy for money supply, energy and economic growth could take into account. These results come from a battery of tests using Granger testing across a range of nominal factors consisting of US money supply aggregates and inflation measures. It means that even as crises occur, the money supply growth rate and the actual inflation rate are able to provide predictive power for these asset prices. The fact that gold prices and exchange rates are similarly affected as are oil prices shows that these nominal effects on energy prices and energy policy are robust phenomena that can impact national formation of energy policy its international coordination.
column19: Max Kenneth Gillman (Role:Author); Sel Dibooglu (Role:Author); Emrah Cevik
column24: UMSL Friedrich A. Hayek Professorship Endowment Fund

column3: US Seigniorage and the Welfare Cost of Inflation
column18: The US inflation tax revenue and the welfare cost of inflation both rose and now are falling in a trend fashion. The paper presents conditions for the trend to continue downwards as based on a money demand based on production of exchange credit. Welfare cost estimates are presented for a 10% inflation rate, a 2% inflation rate and a 0% inflation rate. This contributes how moving towards zero inflation law is feasible, consistent with the trend downwards in seigniorage, less wasteful relative to the inflation tax revenue yielded, and sufficient to fund the Federal Reserve with the natural seigniorage.
column19: Max Kenneth Gillman (Role:Author)
column24: Friedrich A Hayek Professor endowment funds

column3: "Income Tax Evasion: Tax Elasticity, Welfare, and Revenue"
column18: This paper provides a general equilibrium model of income tax evasion. With this, it derives the tax elasticity of taxable income, the welfare cost of the tax, and government revenue as functions of the degree of tax evasion. It shows how a decrease in the tax rate causes the tax elasticity and welfare cost to decrease in magnitude by more than with zero evasion. And it provides conditions by which a stable share of income tax revenue in output can occur over time, even with tax rate reduction occurring gradually. Given a rising productivity trend, the paper shows that this causes less evasion, increases tax revenue as a percent of income, and allows for tax rate reduction while keeping constant the income tax revenue to output ratio. The model is illustrated for less and more productive economies, with sensitivity analysis, and with discussion on how postwar US income tax rate reductions can induce less tax evasion, lower welfare cost, and make for a stable income tax share of output.
column19: Max Kenneth Gillman (Role:Author)

column3: "Explaining Real Business Cycles with Human Capital Investment,"
column4: Journal of Human Capital: Editor Invitation to Submit New Paper following two Referees' and Editor's suggestions
column18: The paper explains the main consumption to output correlation, along with related foci of the real business cycle literature by adding to the standard model external margins for both physical capital and human capital. Specifically a Becker( 1975) human capital investment sector is added and extended to have a productivity shock along with the goods sector productivity shock. This shock to human capital investment causes permanent income effects, within an extension of the Ramsey (1928)-Lucas (188) type model that is Friedman (157) permanent income hypothesis of consumption. The productivity shocks have a variance multi-fold smaller than the standard RBC model, implying greater shock amplification. Data moment correlation, volatilities and autocorrelations are compared to the model. The productivity shocks are backed out so that the model generated consumption to output ratio can be compared to that of the US data since 1973. Capacity utilization rates are also explained within the model and compared to data, as are the main moments of the GDP and GDI data ratios.
column19: Tamas Csabafi; Max Kenneth Gillman; Szilard Benk; Michal Kejak; Jing Dang

column3: Gold as a Harbinger of Financial Calm and Distress Corresponding
column4: Quarterly Review of Economics and Finance
column18: In this paper, we investigate the relationship between gold, silver, and the US dollar returns and financial stress to shed light on the circumstances where these assets serve as attractive investment vehicles and whether the assets signal financial conditions ahead. Using weekly data from 1994 to 2020 and predictability-in-mean, predictability-in-variance, and predictability-in-distribution, we examine the relationship between returns on gold, silver, and the US dollar and the St Louis Financial Stress Index (STLFSI). While we find no Granger predictability in the mean between gold returns and the aggregate STLFSI, there is some evidence of Granger predictability between silver and US dollar returns and financial stress. However, test results show significant bidirectional Granger predictability in variance between STLFSI and gold, silver, and US dollar returns. Predictability-in-distribution tests generally show significant bidirectional relationships between financial stress and gold, silver, and US dollar returns at the left and right tail of the distribution. We confirm the safe-haven properties of gold, silver, and the US dollar and find novel evidence that very low returns on these assets signal financial calm, and unusually high returns signal high financial stress ahead. In this sense, extreme gold, silver, and US dollar returns are harbingers of calm times or financial distress to come, acting as early financial market news providing risk guideposts for safety.
column19: Emrah Cevik (Role:Author); Sel Dibooglu (Role:Author); Max Kenneth Gillman (Role:Author)

This adjustment is the subtraction from the monetary aggregates of the2008-2009 Federal Reserve borrowing of reserves from other Central Banks (Swaps), made after US reserves turned negative. This adjustment is key in that Granger pre-dictability from standard monetary aggregates is found only with the Swaps subtracted.

column3: Szilard Benk & Max Gillman, 2019. "Granger Predictability of Oil Prices after the Great Recession,"
column4: The Center for Economic Research and Graduate Education - Economics Institute, Prague (CERGE-EI) Working Papers
column18: Real oil prices surged from 2009 through 2014, comparable to the 1970's oil shock period. Standard explanations based on monopoly markup fall short since inflation remained low after 2009. This paper contributes strong evidence of Granger (1969) predictability of nominal factors to oil prices, using one adjustment to monetary aggregates. This adjustment is the subtraction from the monetary aggregates of the 2008-2009 Federal Reserve borrowing of reserves from other Central Banks (Swaps), made after US reserves turned negative. This adjustment is key in that Granger predictability from standard monetary aggregates is found only with the Swaps subtracted.

column3: "Estimation of Interest Rates in Alternative Frequency Windows using Simulated Data",
column4: Journal of Economic Dynamics and Control
column18: The paper provides an analysis based on estimation using simulated data of how the bond interest rate can be explained both during the business cycle and during the Medium Cycle. It shows how the standard kernel implies zero inflation tax avoidance in financial markets and instead estimates a pricing kernel in which optimal inflation tax avoidance creates an intertemporal wedge that effects bond rates. During the business cycle the estimation of simulated data supports a robust role for the departures from Fisherian fundamentals due to the inflation tax wedge. In the Medium Cycle, results indicate that interest rates are explained by Fisherian fundamentals, even as the optimal inflation tax avoidance takes place. A wedge such as the one here that results from inflation tax avoidance is shown to be active during business cycles, while a fundamentals only explanation is implied for the Medium Cycle.
column19: Max Kenneth Gillman (Role:Author); Michal Kejak; Tamas Csabafi (Role:Author); Ceri Davies (Role:Author)
column24: UMSL Friedrich A. Hayek Professorship Endowment Fund

column3: Steps in Industrial Development through Human Capital Deepening
column18: This paper contributes a model of human capital deepening, rising education time, and labor shifting away from the agriculture industry. These notable trends in industrial development arise as there are incremental steps upwards in the level of education productivity. As education grows, human capital becomes relatively abundant. Industries react by deepening their human capital investment. The industries using human capital relatively more intensively experience relatively lower prices and higher output. New industries are assumed to arise in step with education productivity. Each new industry is assumed to have a relatively higher human capital factor share. As human capital deepening occurs, labor shifts towards the new industry and away from traditional industry. The paper contributes these features through extension of a well-known model of endogenous economic growth through human capital investment. The extension disaggregates output is into separate industries with varying human capital factor shares. This enables trademark features of industrial development. The model explains rising education levels, growth, and labor reallocation within a minimally complex approach that jointly explains stylized facts through human capital deepening within each industry.
column19: Max Kenneth Gillman (Role:Author)

column3: "Lucas's Methodological Divide in Inflation Theory: A Student's Journey",
column18:
The paper describes how Robert E. Lucas, Jr.’s monetary economies are based on his methodology of using a single general equilibrium dynamic optimization model with microeconomic foundations that can be tested with econometric methods. It shows how, since his 1972 neutrality paper, Phillips curves continue to be a foundation for policy prescription contrary to Lucas’s 1972 results. In support of Lucas’s hypothesis, historical Phillips curves are shown to be idiosyncratic rather than a basis for policy. Using Lucas’s alternative microfounded approaches to money, growth, and asset pricing, the paper then presents Lucas-type extensions for money and growth using a microfounded bank production of exchange credit as an alternative to money, as suggested by Lucas. The paper also shows how this leads to endogenous velocity, money causing inflation, and inflation causing
lower economic growth, as in evidence. This implies that Lucas-based low stable inflation policy yields high economic growth and employment.
column19: Max Kenneth Gillman
column34: Q1 ranked Scrimago

column3: An Explanation of Real US Interest Rates with an Exchange Economy
column18: The paper offers an explanation of historical quarterly real 3-month US Treasury bond interest rates in the United States economy from 1975Q1-2020Q4. Without using the utility of goods as part of the asset pricing wedge, this offers a solution to the puzzle of why standard asset pricing models are unable to explain rates through fundamentals alone. The model adds in a premium that can be viewed as reflecting liquidity by extending a standard exchange economy through the optimal use of bank supplied exchange credit. The paper contributes the closest fit to date, to our knowledge, of real interest rates in an exchange economy without liquidity elements added into the utility function. It explains business cycle filtered real ex-post interest rates, as well as output and labor. It also explains closely the actual level of real interest rates by adding back in the HP filtered trend. Three alternative shock construction methods are used and compared within this monetary business cycle framework that has a sparse set of shocks including bank productivity for the exchange credit sector. Results include robustness and sensitivity analysis, such as comparison to a money-only economy. For the level of the ex-post real bond rate, an iterative convergence shock construction method yields the best correlation with data and a relative volatility near one.
column19: Tamas Csabafi (Role:Author); Max Kenneth Gillman (Role:Author)

column3: The Wall Street Journal Fed Should Slowly Unwind Excess Reserves
column18:
The Wall Street Journal
Fed Should Slowly Unwind Excess Reserves
Before 2008, competition between banks forced them to loan out or otherwise invest excess reserves.
4 Comments 
Sept. 26, 2018 3:15 p.m. ET 
 
SEC chairman, Jay Clayton in April Photo: Yuri Gripas/Bloomberg News 
Regarding your editorial “Sharing the Wealth of Markets” (Sept. 21): Yes, recent stock price increases aren’t creating new wealth as broadly as most would like because the market isn’t providing adequate liquidity for the kind of firms that drive economic growth. We believe that much of the blame rests with Federal Reserve policy. 
The New Keynesian model the Fed uses led, in part, to paying banks interest on excess reserves in 2008. Before 2008 excess reserves were virtually zero but now hover near $2 trillion. This is no longer a rational response to the financial panic of 2008-09. Interest payments made by the Fed on those reserves have helped make major banks richer by not issuing loans from reserves but instead earning interest at no risk.
Before 2008, competition between banks forced them to loan out or otherwise invest excess reserves. This produced new economic activity that produced economic gains outside the banking sector. If the Fed began reducing the interest paid on excess reserves, the excess reserves would begin to enter the system and make capital available to startups by increasing liquidity.
If the near $2 trillion of excess reserves entered circulation tomorrow, it would soon expand the money stock, igniting a major inflation. Interest rates paid on excess reserves should therefore be cut in several stages. But if there ever was a compelling argument for paying banks to hold on to excess reserves, that time is past. The sooner the Fed unwinds this practice the sooner we can avoid frustrating the emergence and expansion of a new generation of wealth-creating firms.
Profs. Max Gillman and David C. Rose 
University of Missouri-St. Louis
column19: David C Rose; Max Kenneth Gillman

column3: "An Explanation of Feldstein-Horioka with Factor Price Equalization", weak invitation to resubmit,
column18: The paper shows factor price equalization within a two-country, one-good, endogenous growth model whereby savings equals investment within each country. Savings moves with investment with changes in sectoral parameters. This theoretical explanation of the Feldstein-Horioka evidence comes with open international trade rather than indicating a lack of such trade. Adding financial intermediation of savings into investment through a single global bank allows equilibrium capital flows, along with goods and labor flows, while preserving the comovement of savings and investment in the face of productivity shifts. Particular attention is paid to the "basic" versus "true" savings definitions of this literature but now interpreted within the endogenous growth setting.
column19: Max Gillman; Joseph Pearlman

column3: Supply-Side Economics with AS-AD in Ramsey Dynamic General Equilibrium
column18: While the Neoclassical dynamic general equilibrium (DGE) model has been applied clearly to the labor market, it has not been clarified for the goods market in which aggregate supply and demand for goods arises. The problem has been the inability to recognize the microeconomic-based relative price that exists with this DGE foundation of modern dynamic macroeconomics. The paper shows that the relative price is the time required per good. It then applies the framework to demonstrate how increasing productivity and decreasing income tax rates can be viewed through a rigorously derived aggregate supply (AS) and aggregate demand (AD) analysis found within the baseline model of Ramsey's dynamic neoclassical foundation. This dynamic stationary theory of value is derived in terms of the aggregate supply and demand for output and its relative price, which is the nominal price of goods divided by the nominal price of labor. The productivity increase and corporate tax rate decrease cause a net shift out in aggregate supply and illustrate foundations of supply-side economics. A decrease in the labor income tax rate causes a proportionate shift out in both AS and AD, rather than the net supply-side shift characteristic of supply-side economics. The paper extends the concepts of AS-AD to derive both a Hicksian, utility-constant aggregate demand with only substitution effects, as well as a Marshallian version that allows both income and substitution effects. An alternative version of the relative price of output as the real interest rate is presented, in which a productivity increase keeps AD unchanged while aggregate supply shifts out. Additional extensions make clear the consistency of the AS-AD framework with the labor market, capital market, isoquant and production function realms, and with the implied consumption function that are well-known standards of analysis, even though the AS-AD foundation to date remains in an unnecessary impasse.
column19: Tamas Z.` Csabafi (Role:Author); Max Kenneth Gillman (Role:Author); Szilard Benk (Role:Author)
column30: Conception and execution of entire paper, with helpful comments from coauthors.

column3: Investigating Cycle Anatomy
column18: Angeletos et al. (2020) (ACD) identify a main shock among oscillations for 10 variables, including Total Factor Productivity (TFP). A striking conclusion is that the "main" shock has little effect on TFP, from which ACD call into question models that make TFP important for cycles. We show that this result is not robust to an alternative definition of the cycle. When we identify cycles with NBER turning point methods, and allow TFP  shocks to be exogenous instead of endogenous as in ACD, they have an impact that tends to be larger than the "main" shock of ACD. TFP matters.

column3: A Human Capital Explanation of Real Business Cycles
column18:
The paper specifies a two-sector real business cycle model with a human capital in-
vestment technology that is tied down with business cycle accounting methods. With
inputs of education expenditure and tertiary student time in the production of human capital investment, the model explains a set of business cycle facts including the
countercyclical aspect of these inputs. Using the time share in labor, both labor time
and its productivity moments are explained along with consumption, as seen in the
related intangible capital literature. With the human capital investment sector provid-
ing an extensive margin for labor time, the model also includes an extensive margin
for physical capital through a variable utilization rate. With correlated productivity
shocks and with the goods sector relatively less human capital intensive, recessions see
human capital deepening that reallocates human capital augmented time shares away
from the goods sector. During expansions, the reallocation of inputs moves towards the
goods sector. Extension includes moment analysis of the main components of National
Income and Product Accounts.

column3: Identifying Money and Inflation Expectation Shocks on Real Oil Prices
column18: The paper adds money supply and inflation expectations shocks to a well-known three-variable structural model that identifies oil price shocks through fundamentals affecting the oil market. Impulse responses show the significance of our two additional monetary shocks in impacting real oil prices. By subtracting from the money supply the temporary Federal Reserve swaps that were used to increase liquidity during the 2008 and 2020 bank crises, shocks upwards in both the adjusted M1 money supply and to inflation expectations significantly increase real oil prices; with the unadjusted M1 aggregate there is no significant effect of money supply shocks on real oil prices. Decomposition of historical oil price shocks shows a significant role played by inflation expectations and the money supply shocks during major oil shock episodes. These shocks partially replace roles previously attributed to the precautionary oil demand shock and the aggregate demand shock during the three major oil shock periods of the 1970s-1980s, post-2008 and during the 2020-2021 pandemic. The results show that both real oil price shocks and expected inflation shocks cause real GDP to fall.
column19: Max Kenneth Gillman (Role:Author); Szilard Benk (Role:Author)
column30: Designing the study, writing the paper.

column3: Macroeconomic Trends among Visegrád Countries, EU Balkans, and the U.S., 1991-2021
column18: The paper provides an introduction to the special issue. It shows a sense in which Visegrád and Balkan EU countries are correlated in macroeconomic performance and integrated with the global business cycles. Using inflation rate levels as a starting point to characterize when these countries began their transitions, it shows that after 1996 both real GDP growth and real interest rates move together to a significant degree both with each other and with the US. This provides a background from which to view the paths since the collapse of the Soviet Union that these transition economies have taken. In addition, comparison is made to US money and banking policy, to provide an outline of how this may impact progress in the transition region. A subsequent summary of the other articles in the issue shows an inter-relation in their themes about how Central, Eastern, and Southeast Europe have progressed since 1991, and how these paths may be affected by Western economic policy.

column3: Monetary Effects on Oil and Gold Prices and Exchange Rates: Theory and Evidence
column4: Journal of International Money and Finance
column18:
The paper contributes theory and evidence on how US monetary factors affect the real value of oil, gold, and USD exchange rates. We find that volatility matters. To advance from linear models as in previous work, we estimate volatility-based Markov-switching regimes within a vector autoregression framework to identify significant Granger-predictability. We combine this with estimated impulse responses of shocks from nominal variables on real asset prices in both low and high volatility regimes. Through the theoretic lens of maintaining the present value of the asset flow with a competitive market return to capital, high volatility times with sudden jumps in the US money supply or inflation expectations cause jumps in the discount rate on the present value income stream that induce jumps in asset prices. Consistent with this we find that in crises periods of high volatility narrower US money supply aggregates and inflation variables significantly Granger-predict and shock upwards both real oil and gold prices. Nominal variables also significantly Granger-predict the USD exchange rate in both regimes. In the
low volatility regime associated with more normal business cycle fluctuations and moderate changes in money supply and inflation, present value theory suggests a stable
discount rate such that oil and gold prices need only change in tandem with the inflation rate to maintain present value. Consistent with this we find that in the low volatility regime, the inflation related variables more than the money supply aggregates Granger-predict real oil and gold prices and shock down the exchange rate.

column3: The comparative effectiveness of mHealth interventions in improving health outcomes: Meta-analytic review
column4: Journal of Medical Internet Research mHealth and uHealth
column18:
For this meta-analysis, we compared the effectiveness of mobile phone interventions to comparison/control conditions at improving health outcomes (e.g., BMI, blood glucose level). We found that mobile health interventions were significantly more effective than comparison/control conditions at improving health outcomes. Furthermore, results indicated that there were several moderators of the relative effectiveness of mobile health interventions. This study adds to knowledge related to mobile health intervention effectiveness and the conditions under which such interventions have a particular advantage over comparison interventions and standard-of-care.
Percent Contribution: 50%
Role of Co-authors: My co-author and I conceptualized and conducted the study together. I wrote more of the manuscript, whereas she completed the data analysis.

column3: Citizen journalism practice increases civic participation
column18:
We conducted a quasi-experimental study to determine the effects of a citizen journalism project on students’ civic participation intentions.  We found that citizen journalism enhanced civic participation intentions (for nonprofit/voluntary organizations) as mediated by attitude toward nonprofit/voluntary organizations. This indicates that attitudes and civic participation intentions may be enhanced for undergraduate students through project-based learning methods.

column3: Dimensions and Validation of the Print Perceived Message Sensation Value Scale (PPMSV)
column18:
For this study, we sought to validate a new scale to measure "perceived message sensation value" (PMSV) for print messages. A scale exists to measure PMSV of video messages, but the differences in print and video format necessitate different scale questions for each format. We found that our newly-developed print perceived message sensation value (PPMSV) scale, consisting of 12 items, demonstrates both convergent and divergent validity.

Percent Contribution: 10%

Role of Co-authors: One of the authors conducted this study for her dissertation and the other two authors were her advisors. The second author conceptualized the study, conducted the study, and analyzed data as well as wrote the manuscript. The first and third authors served as advisors and helped with data analysis and writing the journal article version of the manuscript. I coded messages for the study, along with the second author, and helped with editing and other aspects of the manuscript, as needed.

column3: Social media campaign effects: Moderating role of social capital in anti-smoking campaign communication
column18:
This study investigated the differential effects of a passive online anti-smoking campaign and an interactive online anti-smoking campaign on college students’ willingness to abide by the anti-smoking policy on campus as well as encourage others to do so. We found that social trust and community life satisfaction moderated the effects of the interactive online anti-smoking campaign on behavioral intentions to persuade others to quit smoking and adhere to the anti-smoking policy on campus.   
Percent Contribution: 25%
Role of Co-authors: Namkoong and Nah were the PIs for the project. They were primarily responsible for the conceptualization of the study and analysis of data. Record and I were primarily responsible for collecting data and writing the manuscript.

The Middle Ground Journal is an open-access, refereed and nonprofit journal housed at the The College of St. Scholastica and published by the Midwest World History Association. It is edited by Professor Hong-Ming Liang, Associate Professor at the College of St. Scholastica, in Duluth, Minnesota.

column19: Christoph Eugen Schiessl

column3: The Collaboration Networks of Economic Development Organizations in Eastern Kentucky
column18: This study describes the patterns of collaboration among economic development organizations (EDOs) in eastern Kentucky. Economic development organizations work to improve the economic conditions of their respective locales. They operate in a region facing many historical barriers to economic sustainability, and where resource scarcity is the norm. Given this distressed context, a deeper understanding of how these organizations work together provides valuable insight into practices that promote or discourage goal attainment. Employing a social network perspective, we examine the patterns of collaboration between ninety- eight EDOs currently operating in the region. Data were collected through in-depth interviews with EDO leaders and via an online survey. In this paper, we review the relevant literature and our methodology, identify the population of such organizations, describe their characteristics, and illustrate the various ways in which they collaborate. Our findings reveal that although EDOs share a common mission to promote local economic development, they vary widely in their service offerings and geographic scope, and only leverage about 8 percent of their networking potential.
column19: Jane Jensen; Seungahn Nah; Walter Ferrier; Stephen Borgatti; Sara Compion; Patricia Cook-Craig; Brandon Ofem

column3: (R) Too tight to move? How cultural norms and stereotypes regulate imprinting in hybrid social venturing
column18:
Abstract: Though discussion of culture is central in the literature on gender in entrepreneurial settings, prior studies have paid scant attention to the specific impact of cultural norms. We propose that the impact of gender composition in new venture teams (NVTs) on commercialization of social ventures is contingent on the strength of cultural norms of a nation. Our view of gender as a culture-contingent resource reveals ordering mechanisms that distinguish gender effects in culturally tight versus culturally loose societies with respect to commercialization intent and legal form. The empirical analysis of an international sample of 6657 social ventures from 30 countries supports the study hypotheses. The findings show that gender differences in new ventures are more significant in tight societies compared to loose societies.

This manuscript is now published at the Journal of Business Venturing.

Author contribution: 25%; initiated and completed at UMSL.
All authors contributed equally. Typed double-spaced pages: 42. I collaborated on the theoretical model, helped with analyses, and wrote much of the manuscript.

Journal Impact Factor: 6.000 (1-year), 9.069 (5 years)
(https://www.journals.elsevier.com/journal-of-business-venturing)

column3: (R) All in good time? Founders' age, gender, and patenting in new technology ventures.
column18:
Abstract: Patents are of critical strategic importance in the context of technology entrepreneurship. In this study, we investigate the age and gender-related differences in patenting for technology entrepreneurs. We draw on upper echelons and generational arguments to theorize that there is a curvilinear association between new venture founders’ age and patenting, with distinct moderating effects based on gender. Leveraging a global sample of 2848 new technology ventures across several industries, our analysis broadly supports the hypotheses and provides empirical evidence of the powerful role of age and gender in shaping innovation outcomes for new technology ventures. 

Author contribution: 40%; initiated and completed at UMSL. Typed double-spaced pages: 36

This paper is being readied for journal submission.

column3: (R) Entrepreneurial Orientation, Collaborative Engagement, and Performance: Evidence from Rural Economic Development Organizations
column18: This study examines the role of entrepreneurial orientation (EO) and collaborative engagement on the performance of rural economic development organizations. We theorize that an organization’s EO and collaborative engagement, determined by levels of active engagement within a regional collaboration network, impact its ability to accomplish its goals, satisfy its stakeholders, and influence regional economic development. Our analysis of data from 98 collaborating economic development organizations operating in the economically distressed region of eastern Kentucky shows that EO and collaborative engagement are positively associated with performance. Our study provides actionable insights for leaders of economic development organizations seeking to improve their operations.

column3: Looking at our STEM Teacher Workforce: How to Model Self-efficacy
column18: There is currently a severe shortage of teachers in the US workforce. The problem is especially acute among STEM teachers and exacerbated by high turnover among new teachers – those with less than 5 years of teaching experience. In this paper, we investigate one piece of the puzzle. We model a social cognitive approach to understanding self-efficacy, a key precursor to job performance and retention. Our interactionist approach accounts for both demographic (i.e. gender and age) and relational variables (i.e. social networks). We test our ideas on a sample 159 STEM teachers across five geographic regions in the United States. Our analysis reveals patterned differences in self-efficacy across gender that are contingent on the communities of practice in which the teachers are embedded. Together, our theory and findings highlight the value of taking a holistic, interactionist view in explaining STEM teacher self-efficacy.

column3: Do Corporate Investors Affect Entrepreneurs’ IP Portfolio? Entrepreneurial Finance and Intellectual Property in New Firms
column18: This study investigates the impact of corporate venture capital (CVC) funding on new firms’ subsequent intellectual property (IP) outcomes (i.e., patents, copyrights, and trademarks). The central premise is that CVC funding will encourage the development of technology-centric IP outcomes while dissuading the development of market-centric IP outcomes. Specifically, CVC investments entail a trade-off, which will increase post-funding patent/copyright output while decreasing post-funding trademark output in new firms. Findings from an analysis of a multi-industry sample of U.S. new firms provide broad support for this study thesis and suggest that the impact of CVC funding is contingent on entrepreneurs’ industry-specific experience.

column3: The Use of Visual Network Scales in Teacher Leader Development
column18: Changes in the age and experience of the US teacher workforce have heightened the need for teacher leaders. Based on network-enhanced leadership development models advocated in the management sector, we developed an activity using Visual Network Scales as a pedagogical tool and assessed its utility within a teacher leader development program. Discourse analysis indicates teachers can discuss networks at both ends of a visual density scale, with discussions aligned to community-oriented leadership activities rather than personal classroom topics. Network analysis provides evidence for hybrid network structures explaining the diverse, concurrent set of local and regional activities ascribed to teacher leaders.
column19: Brandon Ofem; Gregory T Rushton; Keith Lundquist; Samuel J Polizzi; William Coyle
column30: Contribution: 20%; initiated and completed at UMSL. Wrote significant portion of initial draft. Incorporated work from the management field. Citations: 1 per Google Scholar.

column3: The Drivers of Collaborative Success Between Rural Economic Development Organizations
column18: The  nonprofit  literature  has  directed  attention  to  exploring  how  features  of  the  broader  structure  of  exchanges  within  regional  collaboration  networks  impact  the  dynamics and outcomes of a single partnership. This study examines how partners’ relative positions within a collaboration network impact their interdependence and collaborative  success.  Our  analysis  of  298  collaborations  between  98  economic  development  organizations  operating  in  an  economically  distressed  rural  region  demonstrates that social network properties—structural embeddedness and relative centrality—have substantial effects on exchange partners’ collaborative success. We also  investigate  whether  network  effects  are  mediated  by  the  two  dimensions  of  interdependence, mutual dependence and power imbalance. Together, our theorizing and results speak to the driving factors of collaborative success in a context where collaboration is particularly vital.
column19: Brandon Ofem; Stephen P. Borgatti; Bindu Arya
column30: Contribution: 75%; initiated and completed at UMSL (but stems from dissertation). Wrote first and subsequent drafts.  Conceived of initial project. Led data collection and analysis.

column3: An Exploration of Communities of Practice in the STEM Teacher Context: What Predicts Ties of Retention?
column18: The STEM teacher workforce in the United States has faced a host of pressing challenges, including teacher shortages, pervasive job dissatisfaction, and high turnover, problems largely attributable to working conditions within schools and districts. These problems have been exacerbated in high-needs districts with fewer resources and more students from low-income communities. Since social network research has shown that workplace relationships are vital for retention, this study investigates the demographic and relational antecedents to what we dub ties of retention. We explore how demographic and relational properties affect the likelihood that teachers have “retention-friendly” networks, characterized by connections important for retention. Our analysis of data from a sample of 120 STEM teachers across five geographic regions identifies key demographics (i.e., site, gender, career changer, and prior teaching experience) and relational properties (network size, positive affect, and perceptions of bridging) associated with ties of retention. We discuss the implications of our findings for the STEM teacher workforce and for teacher education programs.
column19: Jessica Doering (Role:Author); Rebecca Konz (Role:Author); Kathleen Fink (Role:Author); Brandon Rowan Ibiang Ofem (Role:Author); Michael Beeth (Role:Author); Keith Sheppard (Role:Author); Gregory T. Rushton (Role:Author); Gillian Roehrig (Role:Author); Samuel J. Polizzi (Role:Author); Margaret J. Mohr-Schroeder (Role:Author)

column3: Social Network Data from Teacher Leader Development
column18: Social network analysis can draw upon surveys and discussions to generate quantitative and qualitative data. We describe network data generated via a social network survey and discussion activity with high school science teachers in a teacher leadership development program. Data include social network maps related to seeking expertise in teaching content and/or pedagogy, dis-aggregated by contacts at the school, district, state, nation, and international spheres of influence. Data also include transcripts of the activity and teacher discussions of networks in their own educational settings. This data article is related to the research article,“The use of visual network scales in teacher leader development (Polizzi et al., 2019), where data interpretation can be found.

column3: Developments in Accounting Regulation: A Synthesis and Annotated Bibliography of Evidence and Commentary in the 2016 Academic Literature
column18:
(R) In this paper key regulation-related findings and commentaries in the 2016 academic literature are synthesized in annotated form. This paper is one in a series of published annotated bibliographies published in this journal. Papers published in academic outlets including The Accounting Review, Journal of Accounting Research, Journal of Accounting and Economics, Contemporary Accounting Research, Accounting Horizons, The Journal of Accounting, Auditing & Finance, Journal of Accounting and Public Policy, Journal of Business, Finance & Accounting, The Journal of Financial Reporting, Auditing A Journal of Practice and Theory, and Research in Accounting Regulation were reviewed for potential inclusion. The 2016 literature featured strong regulation-related threads as follows: financial accounting regulation, analysis of individual pronouncements, SEC regulatory activity and its impact, international financial reporting standards, income tax reporting, and auditing.

 

Research in Accounting Regulation is classified as a “High Quality” Publication by the Accounting Department and as an “B” on the Australian Business Deans Council (ABDC) Journal Quality List

 

In the Accounting literature article authors are typically listed in alphabetical order when the authors’ contributions are relatively equal.  A non-alphabetical listing of author names typically indicates a significant dispersion of workload.  S. Moehrle contributed more to this article than the coauthors. The approximate percentage contributed by M. Meckfessel and the other coauthors was 15% each.
column19: Jennifer Reynolds Moehrle (Role:Author); He Wen (Role:Author); Stephen Moehrle (Role:Author); Thomas M Kozloski (Role:Author); Michele Meckfessel (Role:Author)

column3: Pandemic-Related IRS Shutdown Affects Tax-Exempt Organizations
column18:
(R) In this article we identify and address a failing with the IRS response to the COVID-19 pandemic.  Many tax-exempt organizations may have had their exempt status automatically revoked without the IRS properly following their own due dates.  This failure left some tax-exempt organizations significantly disadvantaged.   The pandemic and the IRS’s lack of effectively managing their internal processes with respect to extended filing deadlines has had negative unintended consequences for some tax-exempt organizations. 

“Tax Notes Federal” is classified as a “Good Quality” Publication by the Accounting Department and as a “C” on the Australian Business Deans Council (ABDC) Journal Quality List.

M. Meckfessel was the lead author and contributed 80% of the effort for this article.
column19: Greg Geisler (Role:Author); Michele D Meckfessel (Role:Author)
column30: Full paper development; manuscript writing

column3: Reasonable Compensation: Circuit Court Differences Create Confusion and Inconsistency
column4: ATA Journal of Legal Tax Research.
column18:
(R) An incentive exists for closely held C corporations to pay owner-employees higher salaries and lower dividends to avoid the double tax on corporate income. For this reason, the Internal Revenue Code and Treasury Regulations limit corporate compensation deductions to “reasonable compensation”; however, primary tax authorities do not provide a standard definition, leaving the courts to determine what is reasonable and what is not. The courts have generally followed two approaches: a multi-factor test and an independent investor test.

We provide an in-depth exploration of reasonable compensation case law with a focus on disparity within and across court circuits.

We supplement this exploration with an analysis of whether multi-factor determined court outcomes would have changed under the independent investor test. Overall, our findings show disparity in reasonable compensation court determinations within and across circuits and highlight the need for a consistent standard to create tax equity in employee-shareholder compensation practices.

ATA Journal of Legal Tax Research is classified as an “High Quality” publication by the Accounting Department and as a “C” on the Australian Business Deans Council (ABDC) Journal Quality List.

In the Accounting literature article authors are typically listed in alphabetical order when the authors’ contributions are relatively equal

column3: Developments in accounting regulation: A synthesis and annotated bibliography of evidence and commentary in the 2017 academic literature.
column18:
(R) In this paper we synthesized recent regulation-related findings and commentaries in the academic literature in annotated bibliography form. This annotated bibliography is one in a series of bibliographies that summarizes regulation-related academic research. Papers in top accounting outlets such as The Accounting Review, Journal of Accounting Research, Journal of Accounting and Economics, Contemporary Accounting Research, Accounting Horizons, The Journal of Accounting, Auditing & Finance, Journal of Accounting and Public Policy, Journal of Business, Finance & Accounting, The Journal of Financial Reporting, Auditing: A Journal of Practice and Theory, Research in Accounting Regulation and Review of Accounting Studies are included. Threads in the 2017 literature included general regulatory accounting issues, general financial reporting issues, examinations of the impact of specific guidance, and examination of issues surrounding the independent audit.

column3: Are all non-GAAP disclosures created equal?
column18:
(R) Publicly traded companies in the U.S. must prepare financial statements in accordance with the requirements of U.S. Generally Accepted Accounting Principles (U.S. GAAP). However, many companies also report non-GAAP measures—those calculated outside the requirements of U.S. GAAP—in their earnings announcements, annual reports, and SEC filings. The SEC began regulating the release of non-GAAP measures in 2003 and has expressed ongoing concern regarding firms’ disclosure of the same, but the use of non-GAAP measures continued to increase nonetheless. A 2018 Audit Analytics report found that in 2006, 76% of SEC filers included non-GAAP measures, but in 2017 that percentage rose to 96%.

In this article we provide an overview of the SEC regulations regarding non-GAAP measures, examine how investors react to non-GAAP disclosures, and provide guidance regarding how companies can avoid receiving a non-GAAP disclosure comment letter from the SEC.

“Business Horizons” is classified as a “High Quality” Publication by the Accounting Department and as an “B” on the Australian Business Deans Council (ABDC) Journal Quality List.

column3: Meeting the Demands of the Accounting Curriculum: An Integrated Approach Using a Tax Research Case Assignment.
column4: Advances in Accounting Education: Teaching and Curriculum Innovations
column18:
(R) In this paper we discuss a pedagogical approach that incorporates multiple critical topics in the accounting curriculum using an integrated tax research case. Our approach is designed to develop students research, data management and analysis, critical thinking, decision-making, and professional communication skills. These goals are achieved through the use of an integrated assignment requiring students to conduct research, decide how to use an assortment of information sources, conduct analysis of data and business documents, and arrive at and communicate a conclusion.

The key issue is reasonable compensation, a highly litigated tax issue which requires students to identify relevant authority found across many court cases. We created a closely held business with multiple family members with different fact patterns to expose students to different outcomes with a varying degree of complexity. Students were required to analyze business documents and firm-and industry-level data created by the authors to determine the appropriate tax treatment. Further, the case scenario exploits the fact that reasonable compensation is a tax issue in which circuit courts have ruled differently on the same issue, requiring in-depth research and interpretation of primary authority. Additionally, students were exposed to differing outcomes based on entity type.

We provide discussion of our multiple implementations and student questionnaire results to support the efficacy of our approach. We prepared resources to help instructors implement this pedagogical approach, including a completed data analysis, supporting summary tables, and an in-depth discussion of the primary authority related to reasonable compensation.

Advances in Accounting Education: Teaching and Curriculum Innovations is classified as an “Good Quality” publication by the Accounting Department and as a “C” on the Australian Business Deans Council (ABDC) Journal Quality List.

column3: Measurement Operationalization and Written Clarity in Accounting Research: An Integrated Pedagogical Approach for a Doctoral Research Seminar
column4: International Journal of Accounting & Finance Review
column18:
(R) We provide an integrated pedagogical approach that professors can use with doctoral students to immerse students in a decision-making process that is critical to a successful research project: variable operationalization.  Using articles from well-regarded journals to evaluate the operationalization choice of the “restatement” variable, we assemble a pedagogical approach that includes exercises professors can use with doctoral students.  The setting chosen explores three methods used to operationalize the financial restatement variable in empirical archival accounting literature that students can explore: announcement date, first occurrence, and all occurrences.  Students are first tasked with identifying the elements influencing measurement choice.  Next, students assess whether findings reveal that statistically distinct results arise from each of the three measurement choices evaluated.  Finally, students come to realize that an incorrect measurement choice may subject research findings to reductions in explanatory power, risk of type 1 and type 2 errors, and altered direction (sign) of coefficients.  Achieving clarity in measurement choice and exposition are challenges inherent in accounting scholarship.  This pedagogical approach helps nascent scholars work through these challenges using an actual empirical research setting, i.e., financial restatements.  The insights gained can be applied by doctoral students in their own research efforts.

International Journal of Accounting & Finance Review is classified as a “Good Quality” publication by the Accounting Department and as a “C” on the Australian Business Deans Council (ABDC) Journal Quality List.

column3: Variability of Accounting Restatement Measurement in Audit Quality Research.
column18:
(R) In this Article we review 48 recently published articles (2019-2021) in fourteen leading accounting journals that utilized restatement as a proxy for audit quality. We also analyze a sample of 71 articles from early research, 2004 through 2018. Within the combined sample we find three common methods for operationalizing the restatement variable: announcement date (AD), first occurrence (FO), and all occurrences (AO).

Analyzing the research question(s) examined in articles and the operationalization method employed, we inductively develop guidelines that encapsulate the logic applied in choosing the appropriate measurement approach. We find that that a noticeable subset of the 2004-2018 sample (9.86%) did not select the proper operationalization approach. However, 47 of 48 articles (97.92%) in the 2019-2021 period use the appropriate restatement method. Of the 119 combined articles, 89.1% explain why their research operationalization method fits with their research question. However, only 11.8% provide a satisfactorily complete discussion of how they operationalized the restatement variable.

We replicate a recently published article using all three restatement measurement methods and find that the choice made altered both the significance and sign of several of multiple predictor variables. This suggests the need to reexamine prior research that employed a nonstandard measurement choice. Finally, we offer suggestions for communicating the restatement measurement approach employed to assist authors and reviewers in the future.

In the Accounting literature article authors are typically listed in alphabetical order when the authors’ contributions are relatively equal.

column3: How Renewable Energy Policy Intervention Influences Tax Policy in the Top 10 RECAI Countries.
column18:
(R) In this article we explore how energy programs influence tax policy.  The transition to renewable energy has become even more urgent amid soaring gas prices, geopolitical tensions, supply chain shortages and extreme weather events. We compare and contrast how energy policy intervention influences tax policy for the top 10 countries that are accelerating their renewable energy programs to help reduce their reliance on imported energy, based on the Renewable Energy Country Attractiveness Index (RECAI) and history of world’s top 10 global markets since 2003.

column3: Lease accounting standard (ASC 842), temporary book-tax differences, and capital market uncertainty
column18:
(R) Currently, the FASB is conducting a post-implementation review of the ASC 842 lease accounting standard, which underscores the need for academic research regarding the performance and impact of the lease standard in the capital markets. In this study we provide evidence through the lens of tax and capital market consequences. Specifically, we examine the impact of leasing accounting standard-ASC 842 on market participant reaction from the tax perspective concerning implementation from 2016 to 2021. Using difference-in-difference analyses, we find that relative to control firms, treatment firms report higher temporary book-tax differences and experience greater market uncertainty. We show that the increase in market uncertainty among treatment firms is driven mainly by the increase in book-tax differences. Our study contributes to the leasing accounting literature and considers the implications of the ASC 842 lease accounting standard from the tax perspective.

column3: Focusing on the “G” of ESG
column18:
(R) Investors and regulators are increasingly turning to non-financial Environmental, Social, and Governance (ESG) activities in their evaluation of corporate performance. Many audit firms have started offering ESG audits, which both assess a company’s exposure to ESG related risks and evaluate the accuracy of a company’s ESG disclosures. While there have been many articles that focus on the environment and social aspects of ESG our article helps company managers reconsider their governance systems so that they align with a broader range of shareholders and those shareholders’ interests, as well as other stakeholders’ interests. An organization’s goals, as well as the resources that they have available, will affect their governance system. There is not a one-size fits all solution to corporate governance, and each organization will have to consider the costs and benefits of the different processes and mechanisms available to them in order to find the right combination for their organization

“The Asset” is classified as a “Good Quality” Publication by the Accounting Department.

column3: Will Intangibles Trip You Up? Accounting for Income Tax Issues Surrounding Indefinite-Lived Intangible Assets – Lessons Learned from Prior Restatements
column18:
(R) For this award-winning article, my coauthors and I reviewed all tax-related financial statement restatements between the years 2005 and 2010. We identified the two most common causes for those restatements and the accounting and tax regulations related to the underlying transactions described in the disclosure. We identified firms that restated their financial statements due to improper recording of deferred taxes related to indefinite-lived intangibles acquired in mergers and acquisitions and mishandling of deferred tax assets and liabilities on indefinite-lived intangibles in determination of the valuation allowance. An indefinite-lived intangible asset under U.S. accounting principles is one that does not have a legal or contractual limit on its life and in which the useful life is deemed to extend beyond the foreseeable future after obsolescence and other limiting factors are taken into consideration. Examples of indefinite-lived intangible assets include goodwill, trademarks, and some renewable licenses and franchises.

We created a “lessons learned” for firm managers and tax professionals designed to help eliminate the mishandling of complex transactions in financial disclosures.

This article received the 2015 Lybrand best article award from the Institute of Management Accountants.

Strategic Finance is classified as a “High Quality” Publication by the Accounting Department.

column3: An Examination of the Impact of Tax Avoidance on the Readability of Tax Footnotes
column4: Journal of the American Taxation Association
column18:
(R) In this article, we examine the information provided to stakeholders in the tax footnote in the context of readability. The tax footnote is an interesting disclosure to examine because tax reporting requires bridging a vast volume of tax law with financial accounting principles (under ASC 740) and tax returns are proprietary leaving the tax footnote as one of the only public sources of information.

Our paper extends the literature on qualitative disclosures by examining an important firm disclosure, the tax footnote, in isolation.  Additionally, we provide insight into the tax information provided to stakeholders by developing a model of the determinants of tax footnote readability. We find that for firms with relatively low tax avoidance, there is a positive association between tax avoidance and tax footnote readability. In contrast, we find that for firms with relatively high tax avoidance, there is a negative association between tax avoidance and tax footnote readability, consistent with managers concealing information from the tax authority. Our results suggest a firm’s level of tax avoidance creates differing incentives for managers’ disclosure choices.

We extend our analysis to examine whether tax footnote readability impacts investor valuation of tax avoidance. In a model of the association between firm value and tax avoidance, we find investors positively value tax avoidance when tax footnotes are straightforward and firms have relatively low levels of tax avoidance.

Finally, we develop a systematic method of extracting the tax footnote from the 10-K filing. Our data collection method is a combination of approaches, beginning with XBRL extraction (most accurate and efficient) whenever possible, extending to collecting textual filings (moderately accurate and efficient) and finally to manual extraction (accurate but inefficient) when necessary. Our method formalizes and, when possible, automates the complex and time-consuming process of tax footnote extraction for large data samples.

Journal of the American Taxation Association is classified as an “Elite” publication by the Accounting Department and as an “A” on the Australian Business Deans Council (ABDC) Journal Quality List.

column3: First- and Second-Order Effects of Retracted Papers: The Case of James Hunton and the Accounting Literature”
column18:
(R) Through this article we seek to aid the Accounting Academy as it works to repair damage done to the literature by the recent retractions of several journal articles.  The article presents a listing of articles published by Dr. Hunton and notes the recently retracted articles (which includes three articles for which Dr. Hunton was not an author).  This information will help authors to quickly identify retracted articles so that findings from the retracted articles are not used as established knowledge in subsequent research.

The article also provides the following encouragements for researchers.  First, authors are encouraged to verify the credibility of other findings in Dr. Hunton’s papers that have not been retracted. Second, authors that have cited Dr. Hunton’s work in their research are encouraged to review their work to determine whether it relied on findings in a retracted paper such that their subsequent findings could be called into question.  Third, authors are encouraged to add to their initial literature review process a step to verify that none of the papers they are citing have been retracted.  Finally, the article encourages authors to develop alternative ways to provide evidence regarding the research questions addressed in retracted papers in the literature to further restore the literature.   Research in Accounting Regulation is classified as a “High Quality” Publication by the Accounting Department and as a “B” on the Australian Business Deans Council (ABDC) Journal Quality List.

column3: The Not So Pokey Hokies
column18:
(R) “The Not So Pokey Hokies” case received the American Taxation Association (ATA)/Deloitte Teaching Innovation Award for 2017.  According to the ATA, the primary objective of the award is to encourage creativity and experimentation with new and unusual ideas in tax courses.  The award was presented at the American Accounting Association annual meeting in August 2017.

For this tax research case we created “The Not So Pokey Hokies,” a running club based on real people that participate in a wide range of running activities including charitable race participation, not-for-profit running organization management, nationally competitive racing, pacing, competitive team membership, coaching and collegiate sports. This case requires students to identify tax issues related to the club members’ running activities and address the issues using tax research skills. The modular nature of the case allows the instructor to assign specific tax issues or entire scenarios, depending on the nature of the class. As the students complete the case, they are required to use critical thinking to identify the issues and build tax research skills to address the issues. In addition, students gain technical knowledge through exposure to a variety of tax concepts and communication skills through completion of a written analysis of the case. To add to the realism of the case, we created a website www.notsopokeyhokies.com with all of the runner profiles available for student download. 

Issues in Accounting Education is classified as a “High Quality” publication by the Accounting Department and as an “A” on the Australian Business Deans Council (ABDC) Journal Quality List.

column3: The Impact of Big Four Consulting on Audit Reporting Lag and Restatements
column18:
(R) This award winning paper responds to concerns raised by the SEC, PCAOB and scholars over the rapid growth of Big 4 (PwC, KPMG, Ernst and Young, Deloitte) consulting practices. This paper explores the question: Does the regrowth of sizable consulting practices by the Big 4 influence audit reporting lag and restatement rates?

The data presented supports the concern that Big 4 audit practices are not immune to the presence of large consulting practices within the same firm. We find that consulting practice size has a positive and statistically significant influence on audit reporting lag and restatement rate.

Prior empirical scope-of-services research has focused on conflict of interest as a risk to audit quality, with mixed results. The uniqueness of this paper is in our exploration of the theorized impact of loss of professional focus on audit quality. Also by utilizing the 2000-2009 sample period the paper examines a dynamic timeframe encompassing the divesture and the regrowth of Big 4 accounting firm consulting practices and concurrent implementation of SOX scope-of-service restrictions.

Managerial Auditing Journal is classified as a “High Quality” Publication by the Accounting Department as an “A” on the Australian Business Deans Council (ABDC) Journal Quality List.

column3: An Examination of Tax-Related Restatements, Aggressive Tax Reporting, and Tax-Related Material Weaknesses
column4: Journal of Accounting, Auditing and Finance.
column18:
(R) Our research empirically examines the relation between tax avoidance and tax-related restatements, as well as investigating the effects that tax restatements have on future firm tax avoidance behavior. We predict and find that obfuscation of tax avoidance increases the likelihood of incurring a subsequent tax-related restatement. We predict an asymmetric response to a restatement announcement depending upon the level of tax avoidance before the restatement.

Specifically, we document an increase in tax avoidance for firms that have relatively low tax avoidance prior to the restatement event, which we attribute to improved governance leading firms to a more optimal level of tax avoidance. Conversely, we document a decline in tax avoidance for firms that have relatively high tax avoidance prior to the restatement event, consistent with improved governance leading firms to a more optimal level of tax avoidance and increased perceived scrutiny from the tax authority constraining tax avoidance.

Journal of Accounting, Auditing and Finance is classified as an “Elite” publication by the Accounting Department and as an “A” on the Australian Business Deans Council (ABDC) Journal Quality List.

column3: The Chap GPT Artificial Intelligence Chatbot:  How Well Does It Answer Accounting Assessment Questions?
column18:
(R)ChatGPT, a language-learning model chatbot, has garnered considerable attention for its ability to respond to users’ questions. Using data from 14 countries and 186 institutions, we compare ChatGPT and student performance for 28,085 questions from accounting assessments and textbook test banks. As of January 2023, ChatGPT provides correct answers for 56.5 percent of questions and partially correct answers for an additional 9.4 percent of questions. When considering point values for questions, students significantly outperform ChatGPT with a 76.7 percent average on assessments compared to 47.5 percent for ChatGPT if no partial credit is awarded and 56.5 percent if partial credit is awarded. Still, ChatGPT performs better than the student average for 15.8 percent of assessments when we include partial credit. We provide evidence of how ChatGPT performs on different question types, accounting topics, class levels, open/closed assessments, and test bank questions. We also discuss implications for accounting education and research.

Issues in Accounting Education is classified as a “High Quality” publication by the Accounting Department and as an “A” on the Australian Business Deans Council (ABDC) Journal Quality List.

David Wood was the lead author.  All co-authors are listed in alphabetical order.

column3: (R) When do international human capital enhancing practices benefit the bottom line? An ability, motivation, and opportunity perspective
column18:
Abstract: We study the conditions under which firms can capitalize on their international human capital (IHC). Using the ability-motivation-opportunity (AMO) perspective we conceptualize IHC as ability, collaborative climate as motivation, and the firm's level of internationalization as opportunity. We test three alternative AMO models - the additive model (main effect), the combinative model (two-way interactions), and the multiplicative model (a three-way interaction). Using a cross-industry sample of South Korean firms, we find support for the multiplicative model. Specifically, the relationship between IHC enhancement practices and firm performance is significant and positive only when both collaborative climate and internationalization are high.

Google Scholar citations to article as of May 29, 2019: 29
(Excluding self-citations)

Author contribution: 40%. K.Y. Kim and S. Pathak were co-equal first authors on this publication. Initial research as well as submission to JIBS initiated at University of Houston; substantial revision and manuscript acceptance at UMSL

column3: (R) Using multiple intelligences in teaching online international management
column18:
Abstract: This research explores how a multiple intelligences approach can be used to build a global mindset among students in online international management courses. It draws upon research in the areas of global mindset, education, cognition and learning, and neuroscience to discuss how pedagogical tools and strategies relevant to each specific intelligence can contribute to cognitive complexity and cosmopolitanism. Suggestions are offered for online teaching methods that can incorporate the multiple intelligences in international management courses.
